questions.text: Early-onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia occurring before which gestational age?
When is delayed cord clamping recommended?

options.label: A
options.text: Term and preterm babies, irrespective of birth weights

options.label: B
options.text: Vigorous term and preterm babies requiring resuscitation

options.label: C
options.text: Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation

options.label: D
options.text: All term babies born at 37 weeks

questions.correct_answer: A. Term and preterm babies, irrespective of birth weights
questions.explanation:
Timing

Recommended delay: At least 30-60 seconds after birth for vigorous term and preterm infants (per ACOG).

Benefits for Term Infants
  • Increased Hemoglobin Levels: Higher levels at birth.
  • Improved Iron Stores: Better reserves during the first several months of life.
  • Positive Developmental Impact: Potential improvement in neurodevelopmental outcomes.

Benefits for Preterm Infants
  • Improved Circulation: Enhanced transitional circulation to support physiological adaptation.
  • Higher RBC Volume: Better blood volume establishment.
  • Reduced Complications:
    • Lower rates of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC).
    • Reduced incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH).
  • Decreased Need for Blood Transfusions: Fewer transfusions required in neonatal care.

Maternal Safety
  • No significant increase in postpartum hemorrhage or blood loss.
  • No differences in postpartum hemoglobin levels or the need for maternal transfusion.

questions.text: Instrument-assisted delivery is not indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Instrumental delivery

Indications

Contraindications
  • Fetal head at +2 station or below, along with
    • Maternal exhaustion (Option B)
    • Prolonged second-stage labor (Option C)
    • Nonreassuring fetal heart rates and premature placental separation. (Option A)
 
  • Maternal reasons for Operative Vaginal Delivery involve conditions that limit effective pushing or require rapid delivery, such as
    • Severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Neurological diseases
    • Serious cardiac disorders.
  • Mentoposterior position or face presentation
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Preterm delivery
  • Intrauterine death
  • After coming head of Brech
  • Bony deformities of the fetus, such as osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Coagulopathy in the fetus.

questions.text: This instrument is contraindicated for?
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Description

Piper forceps

  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births
  • It has distinct perineal curve, allows for application to the aftercoming head in breech delivery. (Option C)

Simpson forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

Wrigley's forceps

 
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

Kielland forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions. (Option D)
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

questions.text: Following image denote which side of placenta?
questions.explanation:
Maternal surface (Basal plate)
(Options B & D)

Fetal surface (Chorionic plate)
  • Adherent to the uterine wall.
  • It is rough, dull and dark red in colour
  • It is divided into cotyledons by decidual septum.
  • It helps anchor the placenta to the uterus.
  • Contains maternal blood sinus.
  • Receives blood from spiral arteries.
  • The umbilical cord is attached to the fetal surface.
  • It is smooth, shiny and bluish-purple.
  • It is covered with amnion.
  • Takes part in gaseous and nutritional exchange.
  • Highly vascular with fetal capillaries.
  • Facilitates nutritional exchange via chorionic villi.

questions.text: What stage of embryonic development is shown in the following image?
questions.explanation:
DAY

EVENT

Day 0

Fertilization: The sperm fertilizes the egg in the fallopian tube, forming a zygote (single diploid cell)

Day 1

Two cell stage

Day 2

Four cell stage

Day 3

Twelve cell stage

Day 4

Morula Formation: The zygote becomes a solid ball of 16-32 cells. (Option A)

Day 5

Blastocyst Formation: The morula continues to divide and develops a blastocoel, trophoblast, and inner cell mass

Day 6&7

Implantation begins: Blastocyst attaches to the endometrial lining of the uterus and trophoblast begins to invade the uterine wall to start implantation.

Day 14–21

Gastrulation begins: The inner cell mass differentiates into three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), forming the gastrula. (Option D)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 33 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports decreased fetal movements over the past two days. She has a history of gestational diabetes, and her pregnancy has been otherwise uneventful. The doctor decides to perform antepartum fetal surveillance. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial test to assess the fetal well-being in this scenario?

options.label: B
options.text: Biophysical profile Contraction Stress test Non Stress test

questions.explanation:
Fetal movement

Maternal observation and recording of fetal movements to assess fetal well-being and activity levels.

Non-stress test (NST)

Monitors fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements to assess fetal well-being.

Biophysical profile (BPP)

(Option B ruled out)

Assesses fetal well-being based on fetal heart rate accelerations, fetal movements, muscle tone, breathing movements, and amniotic fluid volume

Doppler velocimetry

Uses ultrasound to assess blood flow in fetal vessels like umbilical artery,middle cerebral artery (MCA), and ductus venosus aiding in the evaluation of fetal well-being and placental function

Amniotic fluid index (AFI)

(Option A ruled out)

Measures the depth of amniotic fluid to assess fetal well-being and detect potential complications like oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios

Contraction stress test (CST)

(Option C ruled out)

Evaluates fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions to assess fetal well-being and uteroplacental function under controlled stress conditions.

What is the next step in management?

A 32 y/o pregnant woman presents for her routine antenatal check-up at 28 weeks gestation. She has a history of obesity but no previous history of diabetes. Her fasting plasma glucose level is 104 mg/dL, and her 2-hour plasma glucose level after a 75g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is 167 mg/dL. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: B
options.text: Diagnose her with pre-existing diabetes and initiate insulin therapy.

options.label: C
options.text: Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.

options.label: D
options.text: Monitor her closely without intervention since her glucose levels are borderline.

questions.correct_answer: C. Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

Gestational Diabetes

Pre-existing Diabetes

Timing

During pregnancy

Present before conception

Criteria

Fasting Plasma glucose

92 mg/dL

126 mg/dL (on two occasions)

1-hour plasma glucose

180 mg/dL

≥200 mg/dL (with hyperglycemic symptoms)

2-hour plasma glucose

153 mg/dL

≥200 mg/dL (during an OGTT in asymptomatic individuals)

HbA1c

≥5.7-6.4%

≥6.5%

Management

Resolves after delivery.

Requires intensive management before and during pregnancy.

questions.text: During the active management of the third stage of labor, which intervention is recommended to prevent postpartum hemorrhage primarily due to uterine atony?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate administration of 20 units of undiluted oxytocin intravenously

options.label: C
options.text: Vigorous fundal massage combined with a uterotonic agent

options.label: D
options.text: Controlled cord traction with immediate removal of the placenta

questions.correct_answer: C. Vigorous fundal massage combined with a uterotonic agent
questions.explanation:
Uterine Massage
  • Always palpate the uterine fundus after placental delivery.
  • Vigorous fundal massage, combined with a uterotonic agent, is recommended to prevent PPH due to uterine atony.
  • During immediate PPH, perform uterine massage while evaluating for other bleeding sources and administering uterotonic agents.

Oxytocin
  • Recommended by WHO as a first-line prophylactic treatment for postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Administer 20 units of oxytocin in 1,000 mL of crystalloid solution intravenously at 10 mL/min for a dose of 200 mU/min.
  • Never administer oxytocin as an undiluted bolus due to risks of severe hypotension or cardiac arrhythmias.(Option A)
  • Intravenous oxytocin is also a first-line treatment for uterine atony.
  • Oxytocin 10 units can be given IM with the delivery of the anterior shoulder (Option B)

Delayed Cord Clamping/Controlled Cord Traction (CCT)
  • If placental separation is evident, perform expression via fundal pressure or controlled cord traction.
  • If the placenta is not separated, perform manual removal under general anaesthesia.
  • Delivery of the placenta by cord traction before placental separation especially in an atonic uterus may cause uterine inversion. (Option D)

questions.text: Identify the option with the least risk of TOLAC (trial of labor after cesarean)?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Lower Segment Cesarean Section (CSCS)

Classical Cesarean Section

Techniques

Technically slight difficult

Technically easy

Blood loss is less

Blood loss is more

The wall is thin, and as such, the apposition is perfect

The wall is thick, and the apposition of the margins is imperfect

Perfect peritonization is possible

Not possible

Post- operative

Hemorrhage and shock is less

More

Peritonitis is less even in the infected uterus because of perfect peritonization and, if occurs, localized to the pelvis

Chance of peritonitis is more in the presence of uterine sepsis

Peritoneal adhesions and intestinal obstructions are less

More because of imperfect peritonization

Convalescence is better

Relatively delayed

Morbidity and mortality are much lower

Morbidity and mortality are high

Wound healing

The scar is better healed because of:

The scar is weak because of:

a. Perfect muscle apposition due to thin margins

a. Imperfect muscle apposition because of thick margins

 

b. Minimal wound hematoma

b. More wound hematoma formation

 

c. The wound remains quiescent during the healing process

 

c. The wound is in a state of tension due to contraction and relaxation of the upper segment. As a result, the knots may slip, or the sutures may become loose

d. Chance of gutter formation is unlikely

d. Chance of gutter formation on the inner aspect is more

During future pregnancy

Scar rupture is less (0.5-1.5%)

More risk of scar rupture (4-9%)

Trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC)

Possible in next pregnancy (for 1 previous LSCS only)

Contraindicated due to risk of uterine rupture

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a pregnant woman experiencing bleeding at 12 weeks of gestation, with a normal vaginal examination, closed internal cervical opening (OS), and ultrasound showing a live fetus with156 BPM fetal heart rate at a fundal height consistent with 13 weeks of gestation?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Type

Clinical Features

USG Findings

Management

Threatened Abortion
  • Vaginal bleeding during the first half of pregnancy (before 20 weeks)
  • Light spotting to heavier bleeding
  • Mild abdominal pain or cramping
  • Cervical os closed

Normal intrauterine pregnancy (live fetus, cardiac activity)
  • Bed rest
  • Pelvic rest
  • Close follow-up and monitoring

Inevitable Abortion
  • Vaginal bleeding during the first half of pregnancy
  • Heavy bleeding, often accompanied by severe abdominal pain and cramping
  • Passage of tissue or products of conception through the vagina
  • Cervical os open
  • Evidence of incomplete abortion (gestational sac, fetal parts, placenta)
  • Evaluation of hemodynamic stability
  • Consider surgical intervention (e.g., dilation and curettage)

Rh immune globulin administration (if Rh-negative)

  • Emotional support and counseling

Incomplete Abortion
  • Vaginal bleeding with passage of some fetal or placental tissue
  • Persistent bleeding and cramping
  • Cervical os may be open or closed
  • Retained products of conception (gestational sac remnants, placental tissue)
  • Evaluation of hemodynamic stability

Surgical intervention (e.g., dilation and curettage)

  • Rh immune globulin administration (if Rh-negative)

Emotional support and counseling

Missed Abortion
  • Absence of fetal movements or loss of pregnancy symptoms
  • Uterus stops growing, breast changes may regress
  • Absence of vaginal bleeding (may or may not be present)
  • Cervical os closed
  • Empty gestational sac

 
  • Confirm fetal demise through ultrasound or absence of cardiac activity
  • Expectant management (allow natural expulsion of pregnancy)
  • Surgical intervention (dilation and curettage) if necessary

Complete Abortion
  • Expulsion of all fetal and placental tissue from the uterus
  • Resolution of vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus returns to pre-pregnancy size
  • Cervical os closed
  • Absence of products of conception
  • Confirm complete expulsion of products of conception
  • Emotional support and counseling

questions.text: In a labor room, after delivery and placenta removal, what is the primary reason for uncontrolled bleeding in a multigravida woman, leading to postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
questions.explanation:
Topic

Information

PPH Definition
  • Any bleeding in the genital tract after delivery, including uterine, traumatic, and other causes

 
  • Traditionally, > 500 ml in normal delivery and > 1000 ml in a cesarean section

 
  • Mild PPH: > 500 ml to 1000 ml

 
  • Moderate PPH: > 1000 ml to 2000 ml

 
  • Severe PPH: > 2000 ml

 
  • Massive Obstetric Hemorrhage: > 1500 ml

Causes
  • Atonic Uterus (80%): Large uterus (big baby/twins/↑ liquor), infections (PROM/Chorioamnionitis), prolonged labor

 
  • Injuries (Trauma): Uterus, cervix, vagina

 
  • Coagulopathies: Von Willebrand's Disease (VWD), Idiopathic Thrombocytic Purpura (I.T.P)

 
  • Retained Tissues: Secondary PPH (after 24 hours, up till 12 weeks)

 
  • Primary PPH: Within the first 24 hours (the first 1 hour is the most common time)

 
  • Secondary PPH: > 24 hours till 12 weeks

Prevention
  • Oxytocin is the drug of choice

 
  • Prophylactic IM/IV Oxytocin (5-10 units) after delivery of shoulders

Treatment

1. IV Oxytocin [10-20 units drip] (Drug of Choice)

 

2. IV Methyl Ergometrine 0.2 mg (can also be given IM)

 

3. Tab (PGE1): 1000 μg per rectum (Misoprostol)

 

4. Inj. (PGF α) 2 Carboprost: IM only, can be given intra-myometrial

 

5. Recombinant VII: 90 mg/kg body weight in 3-5 min IV infusion

 

6. Carbetocin: Synthetic analogue of oxytocin; 100 mcg in 1 ml IV over 1 min

 

7. Tranexamic acid: 1 gm IV, an anti-fibrinolysis agent

 

8. Fibrinogen: Maintain > 1 gm/Ltr (>100 mg/dL) using cryoprecipitate or fresh frozen plasma (FFP)

 

9. Uterine artery embolization: Prophylaxis for Placenta Previa, Placenta Accreta, and for treatment in acute conditions

 

10. Intravascular AORTIC balloon compression: Prophylactic measure

 

11. Balloon Tamponade: Examples include Bakri's balloon, Sengstaken tube, Foley's catheter, condoms

 

12. Surgical Methods: Compression/Brace sutures (e.g., Christopher B Lynch), Hayman's sutures, Uterine artery ligation

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed autosomal aneuploidy that leads to spontaneous abortions?
questions.explanation:
Correct option  A. 

Genetic Cause

Description

Chromosomal abnormalities

Abnormalities in the number or structure of chromosomes in the fetus, such as trisomy (extra chromosome) or monosomy (missing chromosome). Commonly observed abnormalities include trisomy 16 and trisomy 21.

Parental chromosomal abnormalities

Structural abnormalities in the chromosomes of one or both parents, such as translocations, inversions, or deletions/duplications. These abnormalities can lead to unbalanced chromosome composition in the embryo.

Single gene disorders

Mutations in specific genes that result in genetic disorders, such as autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant diseases. Examples include cystic fibrosis and Huntington's disease.

Genetic imprinting disorders

Alterations in the expression of genes inherited from either the mother or the father, leading to developmental abnormalities. Examples include Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and Angelman syndrome.

Maternal age-related genetic risks

Increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus associated with advanced maternal age due to errors in meiotic cell division. Commonly observed abnormalities include trisomy 21.

questions.explanation:
Correct Option D: 

Term

Definition

Gravida

The total number of pregnancies a woman has had, including the current one.

Parity

The number of pregnancies carried to a viable gestational age, regardless of the pregnancy outcome (live birth or stillbirth).

Multipara

A woman who has had two or more pregnancies reaching viable gestational age. This includes both live births and stillbirths.

Grand Multipara

A woman who has given birth to five or more pregnancies reaching viable gestational age. It indicates a history of multiple pregnancies and deliveries.

questions.text: In the management of mastitis in a breastfeeding mother, what is the initial treatment approach?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms

Management

Breast pain and tenderness

Apply warm compresses before breastfeeding; ensure proper breastfeeding technique to ensure complete emptying of the breast; pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen as recommended

Breast redness and warmth

Continue breastfeeding frequently to promote milk flow and clear the infection; apply warm compresses to the affected area; ensure proper latch and positioning during breastfeeding

Breast engorgement

Breastfeed or pump frequently to relieve pressure and empty the breast; apply cold compresses after feeding to reduce swelling; avoid tight-fitting innerwear or clothing

Flu-like symptoms (fever, body aches)

Rest, stay hydrated, and get adequate nutrition; continue breastfeeding or pumping to clear the infection; seek medical advice for appropriate management and possible antibiotic therapy

Nipple pain or cracking

Ensure correct latch and positioning during breastfeeding; use lanolin or other nipple creams to soothe and promote healing; seek assistance from a lactation consultant if necessary

Presence of pus or abscess

Antibiotic therapy may be necessary to treat the infection; incision and drainage of abscess may be required in severe cases

questions.text: When is the optimal period to assess nuchal translucency?
questions.explanation:
Trimester

Ultrasound Examination

Timing (in Weeks)

Significance

First Trimester

Transvaginal Ultrasound

6-8 weeks

- Confirming pregnancy and gestational age- Assessing fetal viability - Detecting multiple pregnancies - Evaluating ectopic pregnancies or miscarriages
 

Nuchal Translucency Ultrasound

11-14 weeks

- Screening for chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down syndrome
 

Dating Ultrasound

8-12 weeks

- Determining precise gestational age- Assessing fetal growth

Second Trimester

Anatomy Scan (Level 2 Ultrasound)

18-20 weeks

- Assessing fetal anatomy and organ development - Detecting structural abnormalities
 

Fetal Biometry Ultrasound

Throughout the trimester

- Monitoring fetal growth and well-being - Assessing fetal size, including head circumference, abdominal circumference, and femur length

Third Trimester

Growth Ultrasound

Every 4-6 weeks from 28 weeks until birth

- Assessing fetal growth and weight - Monitoring amniotic fluid levels
 

Doppler Ultrasound

Throughout the trimester

- Assessing blood flow in the umbilical cord and fetal vessels - Monitoring placental function
 

BPP (Biophysical Profile) Ultrasound

Typically from 32 weeks until birth

- Assessing fetal well-being, including fetal movements, breathing, muscle tone, amniotic fluid volume, and heart rate
 

Presentation Scan

Around 36 weeks

- Determining fetal presentation (head-down or breech) in preparation for delivery
 

Position and Placenta Ultrasound

Throughout the trimester

- Assessing placental location and maturity - Checking for placenta previa or other placental abnormalities

questions.text: What is the most suitable treatment option for a pregnant woman who has a history of multiple miscarriages and has been recently diagnosed with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?

Correct option B: Aspirin + H

Clinical Features

Management

Recurrent pregnancy loss

- Aspirin (60-80 mg/day)
 

- Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) starting before pregnancy and continuing throughout pregnancy
 

- Close monitoring of pregnancy with regular ultrasound and Doppler assessments
 

- Consideration of additional therapies, such as corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

Venous thromboembolism (DVT, PE)

- Anticoagulant therapy with LMWH or warfarin, depending on the individual case

Arterial thromboembolism (stroke, MI)

- Anticoagulant therapy with LMWH or warfarin, depending on the individual case

Thrombocytopenia

- Treatment guided by the severity and clinical context
 

- Consideration of corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive therapies

Other manifestations (e.g., livedo reticularis, neurological symptoms)

- Treatment based on the specific manifestations and severity
 

- Management may include anticoagulation, immunosuppressive therapy, and symptomatic treatment

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is unable to pass through the placenta? A. Iron B. Albumin C. Immunoglobulin M D. Immunoglobulin G
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C: B and C

Substance

Explanation

Oxygen

Oxygen is essential for fetal respiration and can easily diffuse across the placenta from the maternal bloodstream.

Nutrients (Glucose, Amino Acids)

Important nutrients, including glucose and amino acids, are transported across the placenta to provide nourishment for the developing fetus.

Immunoglobulin G (IgG)

IgG antibodies, produced by the mother in response to infections or vaccinations, can cross the placenta and provide passive immunity to the fetus.

Hormones (Thyroid Hormones, Estrogen, Progesterone)

Certain hormones produced by the mother, such as thyroid hormones, estrogen, and progesterone, can cross the placenta and impact fetal development.

Carbon Dioxide (CO2)

Carbon dioxide, a waste product produced by the fetus, can diffuse across the placenta and be eliminated through the maternal bloodstream.

Medications and Drugs

Various medications and drugs, both therapeutic and recreational, have the potential to cross the placenta and affect the fetus. It is important to consider the safety of medications during pregnancy.

questions.text: The calculation of the EDD (Expected Date of Delivery) is determined by?
questions.explanation:
Correct option B

Method

Description

Naegele's Rule

EDD = Date of Last Menstrual Period (LMP) + 1 year - 3 months + 7 days

Ultrasound Dating

Determining EDD based on fetal measurements obtained through ultrasound, typically in the first trimester or early second trimester.

Crown-Rump Length (CRL)

EDD is estimated by measuring the length of the fetus from crown (top of the head) to rump (bottom) in early pregnancy.

Biparietal Diameter (BPD)

EDD is estimated by measuring the diameter between the two sides of the fetal head in mid-pregnancy.

Symphysis-Fundal Height (SFH)

EDD is estimated by measuring the distance between the pubic symphysis (the bone in the pelvis) and the top of the uterus.

Ballard Score

EDD is estimated by assessing the physical characteristics of the newborn to determine gestational age.

Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) EDD

EDD is determined based on the date of embryo transfer or insemination during assisted reproductive techniques.

Electronic Fetal Monitoring (EFM)

EDD is estimated based on fetal heart rate patterns recorded during electronic monitoring in labor.

questions.text: Which type of twinning is observed if a zygote undergoes division within 3 days of fertilization?
questions.explanation:
Correct option C

Type of Twins

Description

Characteristics

MCMA Twins

Also known as Monochorionic-Monoamniotic twins.
  • Develop from a single fertilized egg (zygote) that does not fully separate, resulting in a shared chorion (placental membrane) and amniotic sac.
   
  • Have the highest risk among all twin types for complications such as cord entanglement, compression, and twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), where there is an uneven blood flow between the twins through shared blood vessels in the placenta.

MCDA Twins

Also known as Monochorionic-Diamniotic twins.
  • Develop from a single fertilized egg that partially separates, resulting in a shared chorion (placental membrane) but separate amniotic sacs.
   
  • Share the same placenta, which can lead to complications such as TTTS and selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR), where one twin is significantly smaller than the other due to uneven blood flow.

DCDA Twins

Also known as Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins.
  • Develop from two separate fertilized eggs (zygotes) that implant in the uterus, resulting in separate chorions (placental membranes) and separate amniotic sacs.
   
  • Have their own individual placentas, reducing the risk of complications compared to monochorionic twins.
   
  • Can be either dizygotic (fraternal) or monozygotic (identical) twins, depending on whether each egg was fertilized by a separate sperm or if a single fertilized egg split into two embryos, respectively.

DMDA Twins

Also known as Dizygotic-Diamniotic twins.
  • Develop from two separate fertilized eggs (zygotes) that implant in the uterus, resulting in separate chorions (placental membranes) and separate amniotic sacs.
   
  • Are dizygotic (fraternal) twins, meaning each twin has a unique set of genetic material and can be of different sexes.
   
  • Have their own individual placentas, reducing the risk of complications compared to monochorionic twins.

questions.text: In the case of failed medical management, which part of the fallopian tube is most likely to experience the earliest rupture of an ectopic sac?
questions.explanation:
Medical Management Options

Description

Methotrexate

Methotrexate is a medication that stops the growth of rapidly dividing cells, including the developing embryo. It is administered as a single or multiple doses, either intramuscularly or directly into the ectopic pregnancy under ultrasound guidance. Regular monitoring of hCG levels and follow-up is required.

Expectant Management

Also known as "watchful waiting," expectant management involves monitoring the patient's condition and allowing the ectopic pregnancy to resolve naturally without intervention. This approach is suitable for cases with low hCG levels, no symptoms of rupture, and stable clinical condition. Regular monitoring and follow-up visits are necessary.

Combination Therapy

Combination therapy involves administering both methotrexate and a medication called mifepristone. Mifepristone acts by blocking progesterone receptors, further inhibiting the growth of the ectopic pregnancy. This approach may be considered in certain cases, but its use is less common compared to methotrexate alone.

Repeated Doses of Methotrexate

In some cases, multiple doses of methotrexate may be required if the hCG levels do not decrease adequately following the initial dose. Repeat doses are typically given at specified intervals, and monitoring of hCG levels and clinical symptoms is essential.

Surgical Intervention

In certain situations, surgical intervention may be necessary, especially if medical management fails, the ectopic pregnancy ruptures, or there are signs of significant bleeding or hemodynamic instability. Surgical options include laparoscopic salpingostomy or salpingectomy, which involve removing the ectopic pregnancy or the affected fallopian tube.

questions.explanation:
Physiological Changes in Pregnancy

Description

Cardiovascular System
  • Increased blood volume and cardiac output
 
  • Elevated heart rate
 
  • Decreased peripheral vascular resistance
 
  • Slight increase in blood pressure

Respiratory System
  • Increased oxygen demand
 
  • Elevated respiratory rate
 
  • Increased tidal volume
 
  • Altered lung capacity and function

Gastrointestinal System
  • Hormonal changes affect digestion and absorption
 
  • Slowed gastrointestinal motility
 
  • Increased water absorption in the colon
 
  • Elevated risk of constipation and hemorrhoids

Renal System
  • Increased kidney size and blood flow
 
  • Enhanced glomerular filtration rate
 
  • Increased urine production and frequency
 
  • Potential water and electrolyte imbalances

Musculoskeletal System
  • Relaxation of ligaments and joints
 
  • Shift in center of gravity
 
  • Increased lumbar lordosis
 
  • Potential postural changes and discomfort

Endocrine System
  • Hormonal changes to support pregnancy
 
  • Increased levels of estrogen and progesterone
 
  • Maternal adaptations for fetal growth and development

Integumentary System
  • Increased blood flow to the skin
 
  • Potential changes in skin pigmentation
 
  • Stretching of the skin and development of stretch marks
 
  • Changes in hair and nail growth

Immune System
  • Altered immune response and tolerance
 
  • Increased susceptibility to certain infections
 
  • Protection of the developing fetus

questions.text: In the context of a woman who is 31 weeks pregnant and experiencing lower abdominal pain, the clinician is worried about the possibility of preterm labor. Which test would be the most suitable in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C.

Test

 

Cervical Length Measurement

A transvaginal ultrasound is used to measure the length of the cervix. A shortened cervix (< 25 mm) indicates an increased risk of preterm labor and may require further monitoring or intervention.

Fetal Fibronectin (fFN) Test

A swab of cervical or vaginal secretions is taken to detect the presence of fetal fibronectin, a protein that helps bind the fetal sac to the uterine lining. A negative result is useful in ruling out preterm labor within the next two weeks.

Uterine Activity Monitoring

Monitoring uterine contractions using a toco transducer or external electronic fetal monitoring (EFM). This helps assess the frequency, duration, and intensity of contractions, which can indicate the presence of preterm labor.

Fetal Monitoring

Electronic fetal monitoring (EFM) tracks the baby's heart rate and pattern. It helps identify any signs of distress or abnormalities that could be related to preterm labor. Continuous or periodic monitoring may be used, depending on the clinical situation.

Maternal Biomarker Testing

Various biomarkers, such as fetal fibronectin, progesterone levels, and inflammatory markers, can be measured through blood or urine tests. These biomarkers can provide additional information about the risk of preterm labor and help guide management.

Amniotic Fluid Assessment

An assessment of amniotic fluid volume and characteristics may be performed using ultrasound. Abnormalities in the amniotic fluid, such as low levels (oligohydramnios) or infection (chorioamnionitis), may indicate an increased risk of preterm labor.

Microbiological Testing

Testing for vaginal infections, such as bacterial vaginosis (BV) or urinary tract infections (UTIs), can help identify and treat any infections that may contribute to preterm labor.

Fetal Lung Maturity Testing

Tests such as amniocentesis or a fetal lung maturity test (e.g., phospholipid analysis, surfactant-to-albumin ratio) can assess the maturity of the baby's lungs. These tests help determine the need for interventions to promote fetal lung development.

  • ↳ Conization can be performed using different techniques, including cold knife conization (CKC), loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP), or laser conization.
  • ↳ The procedure is typically performed under local or general anesthesia, depending on the extent of the conization and patient preference.
  • ↳ A cone-shaped tissue sample is excised from the cervix, including the transformation zone, which is the area most susceptible to precancerous or cancerous changes.
  • ↳ The excised tissue is then sent to a pathology laboratory for examination to determine the presence of abnormal cells or other cervical abnormalities.
  • ↳ Indications:
  • ↳ Conization is mainly performed as a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for the evaluation and treatment of cervical abnormalities, particularly those detected during cervical screening (Pap smear) or colposcopy. It is commonly used in cases of high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 or CIN 3) or suspected cervical cancer to obtain a tissue sample for accurate diagnosis and to remove the abnormal cells. Conization can also be used for the management of certain glandular lesions, such as adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) or adenocarcinoma of the cervix.

However, under certain circumstances, it may be performed with caution during pregnancy. options.label: A
options.text: Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.explanation:
Definition Choriocarcinoma is a rare and aggressive form of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) originating from trophoblastic tissue.
Etiology Choriocarcinoma usually arises from abnormal placental development after a molar pregnancy, miscarriage, or normal pregnancy.
Pathophysiology Abnormal proliferation of trophoblastic cells, often with aneuploidy or genetic abnormalities.
Clinical Presentation 1. Vaginal bleeding 2. Pelvic pain or discomfort 3. Enlarged uterus 4. Hyperemesis gravidarum (severe morning sickness)
Diagnosis 1. High levels of serum beta-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) 2. Imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI)
Subtypes Pure choriocarcinoma and combined choriocarcinoma (mixed with other GTD subtypes).
Treatment 1. Chemotherapy (methotrexate, actinomycin-D, etoposide) 2. Surgery (hysterectomy if childbearing is completed)
Metastasis Choriocarcinoma is highly metastatic, often spreading to the lungs, brain, liver, and other organs.
Prognosis Aggressive disease, but with early diagnosis and appropriate treatment, a good prognosis is possible.
Follow-up Regular monitoring of beta-hCG levels to assess treatment response and detect recurrence.
Fertility and Pregnancy Choriocarcinoma can develop after pregnancy. Timely diagnosis and treatment are crucial to preserve fertility.

questions.text: A woman presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is being taken for Cesarean section. Which of the following is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on the OT table?

options.label: A
options.text: Supine with wedge under right hip

questions.correct_answer: A. Supine with wedge under right hip
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A

Stage of Labor

Definition

Prolonged Latent Phase

The latent phase is the early phase of labor, characterized by gradual cervical dilation and effacement. A prolonged latent phase is defined as the absence of cervical change for more than 20 hours in nulliparous women or 14 hours in multiparous women.

Prolonged Active Phase

The active phase of labor is marked by more rapid cervical dilation and descent of the fetus. A prolonged active phase is defined as the absence of cervical change for more than 6 hours in nulliparous women or 4 hours in multiparous women.

Prolonged Second Stage

The second stage of labor begins when the cervix is fully dilated and ends with the delivery of the baby. A prolonged second stage is defined as the absence of fetal descent or no progress in pushing efforts for more than 3 hours in nulliparous women or 2 hours in multiparous women.
